header.title: Astral Worship
header.category: Esoteric History, Comparative Religion, Occult Philosophy

central_thesis: The central thesis of 'Astral Worship' is that all primary forms of religion, including ancient and modern Christianity, originated from 'Astrolatry'—the worship of personified nature, particularly celestial bodies. The author argues that religious dogmas, rituals, and symbols are derived from astronomical allegories of a geocentric system, which were deliberately presented as literal histories by an elite priestly class to control the ignorant masses through 'pious frauds.' Theology, according to Hill, is merely the modern designation for ancient Astrology in its dogmatic form.

structure_content.summary: The introduction asserts that modern theology continues the fallacies of ancient astrology, contrary to claims that astronomy disproved it. It traces the origin of primary religion to the Magi, who, confined to studying nature, conceived of a self-existent, soul-animated universe, leading to a materialist view where souls are absorbed post-death. This esoteric knowledge was later exoterically presented as literal history and personified gods.

This section details the ancient Astrologers' erroneous geocentric model of the universe, which formed the basis of their religious system. It describes the Earth as a fixed, circular plane, the firmament as a solid, crystal-like dome supported by 'pillars of heaven' with 'windows of heaven,' and celestial bodies (Planets, Constellations, Zodiac) revolving around it, not in a figurative sense but as real components.

Hill explains the symbolic significance of the numbers seven (representing planets, days of the week, and various mystical structures) and twelve (representing Zodiac signs, months, heroic labors, and foundational elements). These numbers were considered sacred by ancient Astrologers and were central to dedications to planetary genii and Zodiacal divisions in their system of worship, pervading early religious narratives like the Book of Revelation.

The author describes the ancient Astrologers' cosmological concept of a grand 12,000-year cycle, dedicating a thousand years to each Zodiac sign. This cycle concluded with a 'chaos' brought about by primal fire, preceding the reorganization of a 'new heaven and a new earth,' thereby establishing the framework for their 'plan of redemption' doctrines.

This section traces the origin of divine triads (e.g., Brahma, Vishnu, Siva; Father, Word, Holy Ghost) to ancient Oriental astrologers' speculations on organizing primeval chaos. These three intelligences personified chaos itself, its organizer/governor, and the agent imparting life, which Hill identifies as the prototype for Christendom's Trinity.

God Sol is presented as the supreme astral divinity, personifying the sun, conceived as 'evolved' or 'engendered' from the Father's substance (primeval fire/chaos). Designated as God the Son or the Word, he is depicted as the ruling star, embodying both Good and Evil principles, whose allegorical conflicts reflect the diverse seasons and their effects on nature.

The author posits that the concept of God Sol's incarnations every 600 years, born of the Zodiacal Virgo, served as a mechanism for teaching man's redemption. These 'Saviours' performed 'wondrous works' and ascended to heaven, leading to titles like Saviour, Redeemer, Messiah, and Christ, a concept parallel to the Egyptian Phoenix legend.

This chapter links the mythical 'twelve labors' of ancient saviour figures (like Hercules or Nimroud) to God Sol's apparent passage through the twelve Zodiacal constellations. These 'labors' were personified conflicts with Zodiacal 'animals,' beginning with Leo (killing a lion) and including Virgo (rescuing a virgin), adapted into allegories for human redemption.

Hill argues that Christian holidays are directly appropriated from ancient solar worship anniversaries, fixed to celestial events. Examples include the Nativity (Winter Solstice), Epiphany/Twelfth Day, Lent, Passion Week (Vernal Equinox 'crucifixion'), Easter (Vernal 'resurrection'), Ascension, Assumption (Summer Solstice), and the Lord's Supper (Autumnal Equinox).

structure_content.chapter_title: PERSONIFICATIONS OF THE DIVISIONS OF TIME
structure_content.summary: This section explains how ancient solar fables personified divisions of time as deities or figures paying homage to the Triune Deity. The hours were 'Elders,' days were 'Saints' (e.g., St. John the Baptist and the genius of Dec 25 representing increasing/decreasing day length), months were 'Angels' or 'Disciples' (e.g., Peter as Janus, Thomas the Doubter), and seasons were 'Beasts' or 'Archangels' (Leo, Taurus, Aquarius, Aquila).

The author demonstrates how symbols for God Sol (Lord of Good and Evil), such as the Serpent, Sphinx, Dragon, Bull, Ram, Lamb, and Fish, changed over millennia. These transformations are attributed to the 'precession of the equinoxes,' allowing for an astronomical chronology of their adoption as the Vernal Equinox moved through different Zodiacal signs.

This chapter investigates the astronomical and Egyptian origins of various cross symbols. It describes the T-shaped and X-shaped crosses as derived from astronomical alignments (Spring Equinox in Taurus, Ecliptic/Celestial Equator angle) and the 'plus sign' cross from Egyptian Nile inundation markers, which signified either life or famine, becoming central to Christian symbolism.

Hill compares Oriental (Nirvana, Metempsychosis) and Occidental/Egyptian (Amenti/Hades, Elysium, Tartarus, Phlegethon, body resurrection, general judgment) systems of post-mortem rewards and punishments. He asserts these doctrines originated from Astrolatry as priestly inventions to control society, promising happiness or expiatory sufferings.

This chapter argues that 'Jewish Christianity' emerged in Alexandria over two centuries before its modern form. Founded by Hellenized Jews, it adopted Greek and Egyptian Astrolatry, substituting Serapis for their Christ (derived from Greek Bacchus, IΗΣ/Jes). Its Gospel story, monasticism (Essenes/Therapeutae), and focus on the poor were eclectic adaptations.

Hill contends that religious prophecies are not divine revelations but predetermined events crafted by ancient Astrologers, linked to the conclusion of the 12,000-year cycle and the 'second adventism.' He argues that the non-fulfillment of these prophecies historically led the clergy to concoct new scriptures and 'pious frauds' to explain delays and maintain control.

The author traces modern Christianity to the same Alexandrian source, adapted under Roman rule. He claims figures like Emperor Constantine enforced dogmas such as the Trinity for political motives, suppressing original texts and adopting elements from ancient Astrolatry. This period saw the obliteration of classical civilization and the rise of a powerful Roman Church hierarchy.

This chapter presents Freemasonry and Druidism as direct perpetuations of ancient Astrolatry's temple and grove worship. Hill analyzes various Masonic symbols (sun, moon, stars, square, compass, Royal Arch, letter 'G') as originating from Egyptian solar worship and astronomical knowledge, practiced secretly after Roman imperial decrees against the ancient religion.

The Sabbath's origin is attributed to Astrolatry's 'God Sol' resting on the seventh period after creation, mirroring a septenary rest in nature. The author explains how the Jewish seventh-day Sabbath was later superseded by the Christian Sunday Sabbath, enforced by Constantine in 321 AD due to anti-Jewish sentiment, making it a purely human, rather than divine, institution.

Hill provides extensive evidence and quotes from Pagan (Euripides, Strabo, Varro) and Christian (Christ, Paul, Beausobre, Mosheim, Burnet) authorities to demonstrate a historical pattern of deliberate deception and invention of 'wonders' by religious leaders. These 'pious frauds' were used to control the ignorant masses and promote the interests of the church, revealing a pervasive hypocrisy.

The conclusion reiterates that Christian scriptures are astronomical allegories and Jesus a solar myth, asserting that religion is a human invention designed to enslave the ignorant. Hill advocates for abandoning dogmatic religion, recognizing science as the 'true saviour,' and embracing natural morality (the Golden Rule) to create a 'real paradise' on Earth.

key_concepts.definition: The primary form of religion, popularly known as Paganism, founded in the worship of personified nature, specifically honoring the imaginary genii of the stars and supreme adoration to the divinity supposed to reside in the sun.

A sect of philosophers, or 'wise men,' of the Aryan race of Central Asia, identified as the founders of the primary form of religion. They conceived of nature being animated by a great and inherent soul or spirit.

The erroneous system of the universe constructed by ancient Astronomers, wherein the Earth was believed to be a fixed and immovable circular plane at the center, around which all celestial luminaries (Firmament, Planets, Constellations, Zodiac) revolved.

The secret and unwritten system of belief formulated by ancient Astrologers for their private understanding, where the Gods were recognized as mythical and the scriptures as allegorical. This knowledge was intentionally kept from the uninitiated.

The openly taught system of faith for the ignorant masses, where personifications were presented as real personages and allegories as literal histories, often encompassing doctrines of future rewards and punishments for social control.

The supreme divinity of ancient astral worship, personified as the sun. Designated as the 'only begotten of the Father' and 'second person in the sacred Triad,' God Sol was seen as the presiding genius of the sun, embodying both good and evil principles in relation to the changing seasons.

An astronomical phenomenon where the cardinal points (solstices and equinoxes) slowly shift backward through the Zodiacal signs. The author uses this rate of 50⅔ seconds of a degree annually (71⅔ years per degree, 2150 years per sign) to chronologically explain the changing Zodiacal symbols and dates of religious eras.

A grand cosmological cycle of ancient Astrolatry, divided into twelve 1,000-year periods, each corresponding to a sign of the Zodiac. This cycle was believed to culminate in a 'chaos' of fire, preceding the reorganization of a new heaven and earth, linking to the 'plan of redemption'.

The concept of three intelligences (e.g., Brahma, Vishnu, Siva; Father, Word, Holy Ghost) developed by Oriental astrologers. These represented primeval chaos, its organizer/governor, and the agent imparting life, identified as the prototype for the Christian Trinity.

The belief that God Sol descended to Earth in human form, typically at the end of 600-year cycles, to perform humanity's redemption. These 'Saviours' were believed to be born of a Virgin (Virgo of the Zodiac), giving rise to myths of Christ, Messiah, and other divine helpers.

Deliberate deceptions, falsehoods, and invented wonders or miracles employed by the priesthood of various religions throughout history. These were used to propagate faith, maintain authority, control ignorant masses, and serve the interests of the church.

practical_system.description: The book does not present a practical magical system for operative use or provide instructions for performing rituals. Instead, it offers a deconstructionist historical-interpretive framework for understanding the origins and evolution of religious beliefs, tracing them back to an ancient 'Astrolatry' (solar and astral worship) rooted in the geocentric astronomical model of the Magi. It meticulously details how astronomical observations, cycles, and celestial personifications were transmuted into religious dogmas and allegories, often through 'pious frauds.' The 'system' described is therefore one of historical analysis and symbolic interpretation, rather than a guide for magical practice.
tools: The Zodiac and its twelve signs (e.g., Leo, Taurus, Virgo, Pisces, Aries) as a calendar and symbolic backdrop for divine narratives and the 'twelve labors' of Saviours.
The seven visible planets (Sun, Moon, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn) as 'genii' or 'spirits' to the Supreme Deity, influencing sacred numbers (7) and dedications (days of the week).

Constellations (e.g., Hercules, Draco, Virgo, Bootes, Ursa Major) as visual allegories for divine conflicts, familial relationships (e.g., Virgo as mother, Bootes as foster father), and personified forces.

Masonic arms and symbols (sun, moon, blazing star Sirius, square, compass, plumbline, Royal Arch, letter 'G') are analyzed as derived from Egyptian solar worship, representing astronomical knowledge, justice, and the framework of the cosmos.

Cross symbols (T-shaped, X-shaped, plus sign) as astronomical markers (equinox positions, ecliptic obliquity) or practical tools (Nile inundation markers), later adopted and reinterpreted religiously.
rituals: Observation of anniversaries tied to solstices and equinoxes (e.g., Winter Solstice for Nativity, Vernal Equinox for Resurrection), interpreted as reflections of God Sol's 'death' and 'rebirth' through the seasons.
Fasting and penance during periods like Lent, historically linked to demonstrating sympathy for the 'Saviour' during imaginary conflicts with the 'Lord of Evil' (Autumn/Winter seasons).
Sacred offerings and burning of frankincense and myrrh in the worship of God Sol, particularly gold, symbolizing the Sun itself.
Symbolic 'Last Suppers' or Bacchanalias, commemorating the maturing of crops and vintage before the 'Autumnal Crucifixion,' as historical antecedents to Christian sacraments.

relevant_quotes.text: "Astronomy has shattered the fallacies of Astrology; and those of our readers who will accord to this work an unprejudiced perusal can hardly fail to be convinced that a large majority of the people of Christendom are dominated as much by these fallacies as were our Pagan ancestry—the only difference being a change of name. The dogmatic element of religion, which was anciently designated as Astrology, is now known as Theology."

"Thus we see that, although inculcating homage to a multitude of subordinate divinities, the ancient Astrolatry was only an apparent Polytheism; its enlightened votaries, recognizing the dogma of the unity of God, were in reality Monotheists, paying supreme adoration to the mythical genius of the Sun, to whom we will now direct attention."

"Thus we have shown that it was God Sol, the only begotten of the Father, or second person in the sacred Triad, to whom supreme adoration was inculcated in all forms of the ancient Astrolatry; and that its cultured votaries, understanding that the doctrines pertaining to the fall and redemption of man were evolved from the figurative death and resurrection of the solar divinity, recognized the doctrine of incarnation as a priestly invention intended only for the ignorant masses."

"It was ordered in Canon 82 that "Instead of a lamb, the figure of a man nailed to a cross should be the distinguishing symbol of the Christian religion." Now, as this figure is represented by that of a lean and haggard man, with a crown of thorns upon his head, does it not look as if the old Egyptian Demon of Famine was the model after which it was constructed?"

"Thus, having made it apparent that Freemasonry, as primarily instituted, was but a perpetuation of the temple form of Astral worship, we can readily see that, while some of its symbols are as old as the ancient Egyptian religion, it did not, as a secret order, take its rise until Christian persecution made it necessary."

"When we think of the thousand millions of dollars invested in church properties, and estimate the cost of maintaining more than a hundred thousand priests and ministers, in supporting foreign and domestic missions and in publishing religious literature; besides the taxes applied to the care of the religious insane, and realize the fact that all of this vast sum of money is abstracted from the resources of the people, we would not have to go outside of our own country to appreciate the fact that religion is the burden of all burdens to society; and when we contemplate the great disturbance to the social relation, resulting from sectarian strife, and the almost universal disposition of Christians to persecute and ostracize those who differ with them in opinion, we can readily subscribe to the sentiment accredited to one of our revolutionary sires, that 'this would be a good world to live in if there was no religion in it.'"

critical_analysis.relevance: 'Astral Worship' is highly relevant to Western Esotericism and Occultism as it attempts to deconstruct the historical and astronomical origins of religious symbols, dogmas, and rituals, asserting that many core tenets of exoteric religions (including Christianity) were originally esoteric astronomical allegories. It aligns with the occult perspective that universal archetypes and celestial mechanics underlie spiritual traditions. The book provides a detailed, albeit controversial, historical contextualization for many symbols (e.g., cross, Zodiac figures, sacred numbers) and philosophical concepts (e.g., Trinity, incarnation) that are central to Hermeticism, Qabalah, and other esoteric currents. By identifying the 'pious frauds' perpetrated by ancient priests to convert esoteric knowledge into exoteric religion, it implicitly champions the deeper, hidden wisdom sought by occultists. Its discussion of Freemasonry and Druidism as perpetuations of ancient Astrolatry directly connects it to modern esoteric societies.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for 'Astral Worship' includes academic researchers in comparative religion, historians of esotericism, philosophical skeptics, freethinkers, and advanced occult practitioners interested in the historical and mythological foundations of their symbols and philosophies. It is suited for those seeking to understand the allegorical nature of religious narratives and the deep astronomical roots of spiritual traditions, rather than for beginners seeking practical instruction in magic or ritual. It is a polemical work challenging conventional religious interpretations, appealing to those who wish to deconstruct the origins of faith systems.
